While I appreciate the neutral perspective presented here, the problem lies in that these non-controversial issues are all intermingled with the controversial ones. It does not make sense to isolate one particular item we can all agree on from others which are much more polarizing if they care co-dependent when it comes to achieving the stated goal.

From the video: "A goal without a plan is just a wish."

The issue I have with the take in this video is it seems to be promoting just that: a goal without a comprehensive plan. Here is what I mean by that.

We can throw $500 million at k-12 schools for STEM programming. First thing of note, at the scale of federal politics in the United States $500,000 is a drop in the bucket. Sure that's a lot of money for any one individual, but if we split that among the population of 130,930 K-12 schools in the country you end up with about $3,818 per school or roughly $10 per student. Is that really going to be enough to make a difference? Is it better than nothing? Yes. Is it enough? Not even close.

So a major part of the story has to be about the plan. Just throwing money at an issue we all agree needs to be addressed is not enough. How are the funds going to be allocated is one big issue that needs to be addressed. Also some of the more polarizing issues are the ones that some people think will have a bigger impact on the common goal described in this video. Issues like child poverty, access to healthcare, access to technology and the internet at home. There is no point in hiring STEM focused instruction, if the students are too hungry to be able to learn effectively, or if they cannot afford a computer at home because they require life saving insulin that prevents them from having any "disposable" income for these things. These issues are inseparably related and one has to wonder if say, using that $500 million to reduce child poverty might actually have a bigger impact on the goal than enhancing STEM programming at the K-12 level. What is likely the answer is in order to have the biggest impact we probably need to address both issues, a comprehensive plan that takes more than just one aspect of the problem into account.

In order to address the issue and achieve the goal we need to understand why we have a shortage of computer scientists and why they still seem to mostly be white men. According to the video, the reason is there is not enough focus on computer science at the K-12 level. That may indeed be a factor, but is it the only one, or even the primary driver to achieve the desired outcome? The question becomes, where and how do we allocate those funds in a manner that is equitable while also providing the largest impact towards achieving the goal.

So that's the problem. Our plan as laid out in this video seems to be, "let's just throw money at the problem" and fails to take a comprehensive look at the factors leading to why there is a shortage of computer scientists as well as a lack of diversity among them. I suspect that giving that same $500 million to address some of those more polarizing issues like child poverty and healthcare could very well have a much larger impact overall on the stated goal, than just giving an average of $3,818 per school towards the more computer science programming in K-12.

I thoroughly enjoyed the message behind this piece. Sometimes the thing that matters most is listening to what someone has to say without letting a preconceived notion of who they are get in the way. (Admittedly, I've been guilty of it myself in the past and I'm not proud of it, but I won't deny it.) Because when people allow themselves to do that, they can come together and do good things regardless of whether they always believe in the same things. Awesome video; thank you.

Destin, glad you could be part of this event and promote it as you have. I'm always happy to see people try to get skills, not just 'knowledge' in people's brains and hands. To that, as the engineer you are breaking things down to their primitives so to understand how and why they work, to begin to form solutions there is more to the story and realization.

Just as Mike Rowe promotes skills trades at various levels, he can and has only focused on one segment of work at one end of the spectrum. 'Code' is another end of the spectrum.

All of the hands-on skills/crafts, tactile feel, materials, interactions that go into what directly affects humans matter significantly. No matter if or what code is in the process, if the process involves welders or back-loaders - there is a significant contribution of physical/electronic interface between "the code" and "the things" the code senses, controls and ultimately delivers to the humans.

We in the "middle spectrum" of the tech/work world - control electronics, solenoids, measuring sensors, analog-to-digital and vice versa, the wireless 'ether', cabling, power - a bit left out of the "high tech" and skilled labor framing. It's important for wanna-be-coders to realize the things that code does, in real-time, real-life. It's not all magic robots and pushing vapor around 'clouds'. Code needs input and does output. A LOT of soldering and connecting and metering and testing in "our world." Usually the folks who have to 'debug' all this in real-life.

My point is, I hope somehow, somewhere, sometime, someone bridges the gap between highly-engineered brute-force things and their properties, and "coding is cool."

Keep up the good work!! Plus/minus your channel and others - a LOT of us continue to have to be smarter every day!

Thank you Destin for making this video. As someone who is also a member of the STEM community (PhD student in Aero & Astro), I am grateful for you using your platform to shed some light on this serious topic. Resource imbalance in education across communities is a serious issue that needs to be taken seriously. Many people do not understand this and attribute the failure of certain groups to their lack of perseverance and hard work, which is simply not true. However, it is also worth pointing out the difference between equal opportunities and equal outcome. And that is the exact point of this video. It aims to address the current lack of gender and racial diversity specifically in the tech industry not by lowering standard or reserving quota for those people in the admission processes into universities or the industry, but by investing in the early stages of their education, allowing them a level playing field as the rest of the society.

From my German perspective the divide and polarization in America is so dramatic because of the two party system there. You can not think freely about diverse topics and choose the party which is best suited because there is no diversity in political parties. Your only option is to accept all the bad things of your preffered party and denounce the other party despite of the good ideas they might have just to ensure that they wont get the majority vote. Since there is no diversity it's most likely your family or friends are also almost all belonging to the same party and therefore are getting influenced to allign most of their opinions with this party (echo-chamber-effect). How can you even argue freely about diverse topics if any opposing idea makes you a outcast to the political consensus your family or friends hold?

So I am a senior in high school about to graduate, and I have been learning about programming since 7th grade. I think it's great that people are trying to get programs into schools. But here's the thing: coding isn't just about a language, but rather the critical thinking behind it. I've learned parts of multiple languages over my 5 years of programming, but the best part is taking an issue and finding the solution. That's just science! As noble of a cause this is, I feel it might just sort of fall apart. I personally love learning, and at this point learn by reading stuff like the Mozilla Documentation and doing projects. It's like sitting with a bunch of physics formulas and doing experiments, and I absolutely love it. Kids in my school though, they could care less. One kid argued with a teacher about being late to class because his bag was there even though he wasn't. Sure, getting these classes will help kids learn, but kids need to want to learn. I live in a rural town, and I make jokes about our school being poor, but in reality it's not funny. We can't afford to have enough teachers to do classes, and one teacher left partly from being overworked. There's no discipline because parents don't do it at home and complain because the school is doing it for them. When teachers are out, multiple classes at a time are put under one substitute who basically babysits all of them. School is a place for me to want to learn, but I'm a rare breed called an honors student (which is a fancy code word for how students really should be). I feel the public education system doesn't work well (at least my school), and I wish more kids would love learning as much as I do. I binge watch channels like Smarter Every Day, Minute Physics, Vsause, 3Blue1Brown, and other channels like these just because I love learning.

Either way, computer science has been awesome for me, and everything I learned was really from me teaching myself, not something my school offered. Schools should help kids to love learning, and be a way for kids to reach out to learn what they need to make this world a better place for themselves, their current and future families, and everyone else on this planet.

I am happy to see a goal to get computer programming into schools. I have said often that everyone should learn at least one computer language of any kind even if it is a simple scipting language. If I was a principal or someone in control of a school I would include computer science as one of the major subjects. It would have done a lot to improve my personal experience with school and I believe it would help many kids get a more balanced education. A lot of people are not great at doing math expecially without a calculator and the likely reason is that they are not shown what mathematics can do for them later in life and why math is important to know. So many times I was told sometimes by the math teacher that what was being taught is not likely to ever get used again as an adult, so why would I or anyone who is told that or thinks that ever focus on learning about the solution to a problem that won't show up ever again outside the classroom? A computer science class would solve that lack of applied usefulness of the subject, which would do a lot to get kids to focus more on learning the subject since it is no longer a useless subject you have to take to get a diploma. It would also bridge interest between math, science and writing  and help demonstrate application for the information being taught. So beound computer science being a useful subject that everyone could use on a daily basis to improve and make efficiencies in their lives if they knew how to code but it would improve interest in most of the other subjects as well.

I have been a programmer for many years.  Moving from project to project.  Most often the programming languages used for each project stay the same but the business requirements in each project are always different. That's what makes it challenging. It's all done using The System Development Life Cycle methodology framework

It is frustrating to see society focus on the differences between people and then letting those differences create a wedge of divisiveness.  Why not let the high level, important things we DO agree on (safe streets, opportunities for our children, strong and resilient communities, good education) serve as a foundation on which we build a strong and stable society,  one that can handle the things it disagrees on with civility and integrity.  I've found that when disagreement is coupled with respect for the other's opinion, I am better able to understand the underlying values of that disagreement and am better able and more willing to work to find a resolution that serves us both.  I suspect most people would agree on real key things that matter in life (food, safety, shelter, health, education, hope for the future) even if we think there are different ways to make those manifest. No side of the political spectrum has a monopoly on good ideas.

$50 mil is only 0.4% of Facebook's annual revenue (for example), and $500 mil is only 0.23% of Uncle Sam's annual education budget.  How is that going to make a difference? About half of the 50.7 million K-12 students expected to attend class this Fall are not white; for argument's sake, let's let the remaining 50% (about 25 million) students be the minorities targeted by this initiative.  The math comes out to around $20/student FOR THE YEAR. This is a financial drop in the bucket that allows all involved to feel warm and fuzzy about "doing good" while truly serious and potentially devastating issues remain unaddressed and unchecked.  One is likely inclined to say "Well, at least they're doing SOMETHING, right?" And? That something is like trying to raise the Titanic with the air from a single ping pong ball (sorry, I don't have the exact metrics for that).  "What if we all pitched in?" Ok, that's better, but let me ask you this; when was the last time we all got off our duff and did the right thing? We couldn't even bother to vote as a nation in an election that divided the nation more thoroughly than any in recent history?  So,, long story short, if you expect corporations and government to take care of you and/or your kids, you're hosed.  You want your kid to succeed? Teach them yourself, raise them with a sound moral compass, and make sure they know how to get by as much as possible without entitlements.

Honestly, more parents need to volunteer to teach kids how to think analytically. Those skills will apply to any STEAM (science, technology, engineering, art, math) studies or jobs. More important than learning "how to code" is "how to learn". We don't need more coders for the future. We need people who can learn new things quickly and solve new problems. Many of the problems we are attempting to solve with code today requires knowledge and experience in multiple disciplines.  Take machine learning for example. You need programming skills, experience with the tools (tensorFlow, DeepLearning4Java, OpenAI, MXNet, etc) and subject matter expertise. It's not enough to just "code" and coding camps aren't addressing the real issue. As a programmer and R&D guy, it's more than just coding. Teaching kids to code is a good first step, but more important is "learning how to learn."

I've been CS all my life, starting programming in the 70s, self-taught for years before college in the 80s, and have been doing CS and IT non-stop. I know coding.

While I wish I had had CS in K12 school (we didn't have computers in my high school until the year after I graduated), I have learned through the school of hard knocks that pure CS is next to useless without a strong basic education in all other disciplines: math, physics, english, history, social studies, chemistry, engineering, even personal finance and physical education. Why? Because APPLYING CS is just as important as CS itself. Great, teach kids how to code, but if they can't pass the rest, they won't know how to APPLY that knowledge.

I know LOTS of coders; some of them are really sharp people, but if you spend more time teaching them things they should have learned in K12 than it takes to get a job done, that knowledge really doesn't mean much. So, yeah, while it is great that we're spending a paltry $500M on one tiny area of vocational knowledge, let's spend the rest of the billions necessary to get them just as competent in the core knowledge and skill areas they will need to make that one tiny area actually useful.

I'll also point out that low-end programming jobs don't pay a whole lot more than subsistence-level wages, and a glut of low-end programmers coming out of high school won't improve that figure; more than likely will lower it, which is a possible motivation for these big companies to put forward this kind of money, because they will make it back from lower human resources costs; ie, lower wages across the board.

Yes, that sounds dark, but that's capitalism in a nutshell; corporations' SOLE goal is to maximize profits. Creating a glut of CS lowers wages across the board. Now, maybe some people are ok with that. In many years in business, I have received not an insignificant amount of pushback on the cost of IT - people complaining about having to pay more, despite prices being on the low side of the market averages for services. However, the only way those prices can go down in a so-called "free market" is if you can pay the people doing the work less. Profits aren't going to go down just because people want lower prices.

All that aside, I think this is a good start, despite my misgivings as to the motivations of the government and corporate backers. Now, we just need to get this kind of energy behind the rest of our educational system and core subjects as well. It won't be anywhere as cheap as this, but it is ultimately a Good Thing, too.

As a senior student working to his Bachelor of Computer Science degree, I would like to warn that -- at least in my university -- computer science is taught incredibly badly.
I can't say how it would be implemented into high schools, but as far as my university goes, I've only had two true classes about teaching a high-level language (C++); every other class has either felt super unfocused or just plain irrelevant. Like how we had to properly learn to read and write in MIPS (the assembly language) for just one class -- the class that already wanted you to learn how basic processors compute information, how to do various calculations on binary numbers by hand, how to convert MIPS instructions to and from binary data (again, by hand ), etc... Haven't had to write a single line of MIPS since.
Also pretty fun taking required math classes like Calculus 2 which are designed with no calculators in mind. I get that students need to understand derivatives and integrals before they just plug them into calculators, but when over half of Calculus 1 and Calculus 2 is just about simplifying them by hand -- when we're computer science students -- it gets really demotivating.
And besides the main classes just being badly taught, they also mostly bias to teaching how hardware works. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it's something to take note of if you ever want to study anything about computers. "Computer science" is a super-broad name, and honestly, I wish I had realized that sooner -- understanding and programming for an operating system is a whole different world than programming in a high-level language (as you would for most occupations). And even still, those are both so different from datamining, networking, etc.
Do not repeat my mistake -- make sure your university is decent at teaching computer-related courses (i.e. not FSU) and make sure you know exactly what you want to learn.

I love the sentiment and I love your videos, but I question putting GOVERNMENT money into influencing career choices of our children.  Making sure they are exposed to technology is one thing, and private money is an awesome thing, but your comment about your sister's starting salary being 150% of yours shows that the market forces will naturally work to encourage more people to enter the CompSci field.  Honestly, I think the shortage of skilled blue collar workers is a larger problem in this country in the longrun.  Our decades old mantra that everyone should get a college degree has proven to encourage many who dont have the passion or aptitude for a degree driven career to pursue one anyway, which has just left them jobless or unhappy in a career with a large college debt.  Those same people may have been perfectly happy and successful as a plumber, electrician, welder, construction worker, etc.  I agree we should educate kids as best we can, and expose them to as many different lines of work as possible, but we need to be careful when we encourage people to take careers because of a shortage of a talent in society rather than for them to take a job that they are passionate about.    You are right that the mission to Mars will have millions of lines of code on it, but that ship that they are on will also have to be built by real people with real physical skills.  That being said, I appreciate your goal of working together toward common goals, and not focusing on divisive disagreements!!  Keep up the good work!!

I've worked for a School District, in Utah for 26+ years. Since I've worked there, personal computers and the networks that link them, have made huge leaps in technology. ie: In 1991 we had a High School building, that had 6 different types of networks. Ethernet, ARCnet, Thin-lan, Token-ring, HP net, Apple Talk A, Apple Talk B.
It was like the Tower of Babel for computers. None of them could talk to each other.
Jump to the present day, we have massive Ethernet networks. Each student has access to a Tablet computer and multi channel WiFi.

I understand that "Computer Science" is being used as a term that general populace will understand, but from an implementation standpoint, we need to make sure everyone is actually talking about the same thing

1) CS has nothing to do with programming or coding. Actually it has nothing to do with computers, just the computability of something.
2) Programming has nothing to do with coding, it's just problem solving. Nothing more, nothing less.
3) Coding is menial labor that I hope AIs will do soon.

I see "coding" in school something akin to learning art or history. It's something people should know about, but school won't teach you anything useful. Even at my University, my "programming teachers" all said that their job was not to teach us knowledge, but how to teach ourselves. Tech moves fast. In 2-3 years, half of your knowledge will be useless, and it's getting worse as tech moves faster and faster. Knowledge is a wasteful goal. Understanding is the only thing useful.

Most of the best books on "programming" are back from the 60s and 70s. Nearly (not all) every problem you see in tech, software wise, was solved 60 years ago. What you see is programmers struggling to understand the issues they are presented in an ever so slightly different way and re-inventing the wheel because they don't have the basic understanding to apply the solutions made decades ago.

Programming is an interesting problem domain. Many people make analogies to programming like building a house. Yes, some of programming is knowing about your tools and materials. But what's really awesome about programming is every programmer can not only make their own tools, but their own materials. It's like making your own universe with it's own custom rules, governed only by logic. You can make a material denser than a neutron star or stronger than graphene, or super conductive at any temperature, maybe your universe has many more than 3 spatial dimensions. Then you build a house using those materials in that maybe 12 spatial dimensional universe.

Using this analogy, it would be like becoming a surgeon, where you not only fix biological beings, but you designed the biological beings using your own rules for biology. How could anyone teach you anything about surgery on an organism that has never been seen before and in a universe with completely different rules for biology? You can't. But you can teach someone how to think like a surgeon. That is what programming is all about.

Here in lies the rub. How do you teach someone to think? You can't, they must learn for themselves from themselves. You can only expose them to situations that allow them to have to think in novel ways. Schools need better critical thinking classes, not "coding" classes, but something is probably better than nothing.

I graduated in 2000. From K-12 I was in some sort of CS class. I started on a green screen Apple 2e. I started with BASIC, which helped me program my TI-83.

This has to be a good thing but I would caution against concentrating on coding alone. I retired 8 years ago after 43 years in Information Technology. When I started working in the industry in 1968 there was no body of knowledge in IT to study. If you could pass an aptitude test you were in. There were not many jobs available I think there were 3, yes 3, in my home town. You basically sank or swam on your innate ability to reason. Fortunately I swam, doing every type of work in the IT field, Programming, starting with IBM Assembler, the Cobol until finally I had programmed in 11 languages. It is true that if you can program, and some people cannot, it is actually an easy job, it is designing and building systems that is hard (Systems Analysis and Design and Project Leadership), and before I acquired the tools to do it nearly broke me. Fortunately that system went in smoothly and I emigrated from the UK to work for Ford Australia. As time went on I owned a small Consultancy company with 2 friends. I did some good work for 16 years, the first consultancy project I worked on, a 2 year project, ran for for 39 years before the client re developed it. Others ran for 20 years and, I was pleased to discover could not process the work load as fast as mine. That has to be up there for longevity!

Eventually my technology platform was becoming obsolescent and I moved into 'management' with a State Government Department. After years of controlling my own destiny I did not enjoy middle management but resigned from Government Service as Enterprise Architecture Manager. Sounds great doesn't it? It wasn't!

However after a career programming, the easy stuff, and deriving User Requirements (The most important step) and then designing and documenting systems, it became apparent that the world had changed and there were fewer and fewer customers for Custom Systems and more and more 'Standard Systems' for sale. Customer management was becoming more and more gun shy of Custom System and would prefer to buy a package because, cynical me, they wanted to out source the responsibility for success, or rather failure of system development. The major problem with this approach is that they NEVER DEFINED THEIR REQUIREMENTS before buying a 'solution.

Here is the main point of my post. The one thing technical area, in my opinion, that will never become obsolete is Computer Security Management, not system development. My son, now in his 40's trained as a Systems Developer, but has worked on Computer Security ever since he started work in IT. He is very good at it and has global responsibility for thousands of computers in an International company. He now earns twice what I earned as an employee when I retired. As a company owner I rarely earned what he does today.

So, in my opinion the best fields to enter are not coding but Business Analysis and Computer security.

Political stuff aside... regarding the choice of major, I’m an electrical engineer and have closely worked with computer scientists on embedded applications for 20+ years. I somewhat agree with your assessment of the job industry, but at the same time my personal experience in interviewing candidates for many years is that good EEs are extremely difficult to find and are a gem when you do. Furthermore, some of the best embedded computer scientists I’ve ever worked with have degrees in Physics, not CS. What they bring to the table is an intrinsic understanding of the physical hardware running their target applications. A lot of CS people are missing that. If you choose to go CS, my recommendation is to include, in your electives, some exposure to electronics or at least Physics.

Hey Destin,

First of all, let me say Thank you.
Thank you and all of the YouTube STEM community for providing the things that I never had as a child growing up, and questioning the ideals that I would never had thought to.

Secondly, My Story. As a child growing up in Australia in the late 90's coming from a poor family, I had never thought that today I would be where I am now. I never treated high school seriously but was always interested in computers. At the time, that was a nerdy thing. I didn't have a computer at home, so learning things made it difficult.

Eventually I made my way to TAFE (which is essentially what I assume US calls community college), and there I started Network Engineering. Through that course, I found love with coding. Coding is now my life. Problem solving.

I hated algebra at high school, now I look back on it, that's now my life. I love solving problems. I love my job. I don't have any university qualifications, but, I have heaps of experience and ideas behind problem solving, how to 'deal with situations' and that attribute positive momentum to my every day life.

I stuffed about a bit in high school, but have always been interesting in Science. Channels like yours, SciShow and Veritasium have help me gain knowledge into the area in which I now move forward in.

I'm glad you made this video, because knowledge shouldn't be about government, or how much money you have. It should always be about knowledge. It is human nature to be inquisitive and to learn, and solve problems. Everything, every day, is a problem, and it's dependent on how you apply your thoughts and experience to solving that problem.

We shouldn't be holding the torch away from others, we should be holding it closer to aid humankind. We all benefit from shared knowledge.

I'm all for diversity in the workplace, but at the same time the fact is that some types of people are more suited to certain jobs than others. There's a reason you don't see as many women in the Alaskan Crab Fishing, or Coal Mining jobs: women are generally less physically strong. I think that positions like those, and like STEM fields should have equal opportunity for all people. No one person or group should be discouraged or encouraged more than any other. And the fact is, you will inevitably see some numbers that aren't perfectly representative of the population. (As long as you offer classes in Gender Studies and such, where opinions are the only facts, you'll get people taking those classes instead of, you know, learning things.)
So again, I'm all for diversity in the workplace, but I hate the thought of forcing it. Things like this say "we're making a big push to get more women, blacks, hispanics, and other minorities into STEM fields, but if that's your goal, you're going to end up with people giving out jobs based on who's not a white male.

My point is, don't focus on minorities, focus on everyone.

I work in one of those industries that you don't normally think of when it comes to coding: agriculture. In fact, the company I work for is one of only a small handful writing code to help farmers around the world. Think about it, it affects the global food chain. The more efficiently we can use the land and the more productive we can make it, the less we need to actually cultivate. Look up vertical farming if you want to see the future. I would describe the purpose of the code we write and the systems we build with it as "gathering and interpreting farm telemetry". This whole area of computing is where Google was 17 years ago; that's the kind of growth we anticipate.

I’m a conservative white 52-year-old male college dropout making a modest living as a researcher/programmer. Yet, I’ve put my wife through college (graduating last May with a degree in STEM education) while my son is a year away from a degree in Robotic Engineering and my daughter is a freshman working toward a degree in Automotive Engineering.
All this without student loans or money out of my pocket! How? There’s buckets of money out there all geared toward earning a diploma, even for white folks like us. But you have to work at it.

Both my kids live at home and have jobs to pay for their cars, gas and insurance. I put in a 10-hour day then come home and make dinner (leave the kitchen spotless!) and make sure both kids are on track (I have all of their homework assignments and exams schedules in my calendar). My wife handles laundry and the kids have their chores. My wife is a public middle school math and science teacher for 120 kids which means a lot of 12-hour days. Weekends I help her with grading papers, keeping her class website up-to-date and assembling fun science projects for her lesson plans.

Finally, at this time of year I’m scouring the internet for grants, scholarships and programs to pay next year’s tuition. By Christmas the essays are written, the applications submitted and by spring the money comes rolling in.

So, to all those outraged white males, turn off the tv with pundits telling you how unfair society is treating you, stop salivating over memes on Facebook that heighten your anger, get off your pathetic keisters, man up and get to work!

Destin, I love your videos and I love that you try to keep them apolitical. However, I have to say, I don’t agree that it is necessarily good to just say you are focusing on the good thing (i.e. the money that was donated) and ignore where the money charities receive comes from, and why it was donated. If I murder someone for their money, then donate some of that to a charity, sure, the charity benefits, but was that good? If I donate to a charity for kids just so I can win their trust and get “close” to one of the kids, again, the charity benefits, but was that good? If a charity takes money they know comes from an inappropriate or illegal source or for inappropriate reasons, I think they are partially implicit. And it isn’t much better to just say, “I don’t want to know where this money is coming from.”

These companies are giving this money, not as a PR stunt, but due to simple economics. There is a huge shortage of quality engineers, which means that finding talent is difficult, highly competitive, and perhaps most importantly, expensive. Engineers cost a lot of money, and this is not money that these companies want to pay. Just a few years ago, several of these companies were successfully sued when they were caught colluding with each other to not poach each others engineers and to drive down wages.

All that said, I'm not completely cynical. I'm sure most of these people believe in this project for the right reasons, and even if they don't you're correct to point out that it doesn't really matter. A good thing is a good thing.

As a software engineer myself, I desperately want to see more diversity in the field. And if a large influx of new engineers accomplishes the goals of these companies by driving down wages, and making diversity hiring less expensive, then so be it. Because those new engineers are my fellow citizens and I think this will strengthen our middle class. And perhaps even heal some divisions eventually.

Focusing on what is agreed on does not always make more progress than focusing on what is disagreed on. Assume people can have any possible position in any situation (this seems pretty self-evident). Let Alice and Bob be people trying to decide what to work on to maximize progress. Alice wants to focus on agreements and Bob wants to focus on disagreements. Then clearly working to maximize progress involves working on a disagreement. So to work on an agreement would make no progress on the problem at hand. But working on the disagreement would make progress since it is possible Bob changes his position. Therefore it is not always more important to focus on agreements than disagreements. xD

I mean, sure, $500M IS a lot of money, especially so when you look at it like one lump sum. When I was in high school I took a computer science class. I was so excited in the beginning but was highly disappointed in the class. Unfortunately they hired a teacher with a PhD, who taught like we should already magically know certain concepts, but this was supposed to be an introductory course. He taught only with presentations, and there were no textbooks or printouts to help us study, many people dropped out. When I tried to drop the class my counselor met with the teacher and I, and he asked me why I wanted to drop the class. I explained that I didn't understand any of the material and there was nothing for me to fall back on. My teacher looked at me, then told my counselor that I wasn't paying attention in class and that's why I didn't understand, essentially calling me a liar. I was not allowed to drop the class, even after my mother explicitly called the school to request I be given a study period. I had to take an F for that course because I refused to cheat like the remaining few students in the class who copied off the only person who knew what they were doing. I firmly believe that the only reason I wasn't allowed to drop is because they couldn't justify keeping the class open with so few students left, and they were paying this guy just over a 100k a year to teach.

Until I retired from teaching a few years ago I taught ICT (Information Communication Technology, otherwise known as computers) in a small school in North East England. I loved my job and was confused and angry when the subject was cut from the national curriculum, even though it was replaced with Computing. The reason was it was done so fast that the subject wasn't thought through so even though I agreed that coding was important no one knew how to actually teach it to kids.

Code.org made the difference. I am sure it is better now but even back then it made my job possible. It gave me the tools and skills I needed to encourage and enthuse a population of children who really didn't care about coding. When we tried to introduce game theory to them their response was they wanted to play games, they weren't interested in who actually created them or in building the skill set needed to become computer scientists.
Let's get more programmers, so we can employ more and thus pay them less.

I agree that you need to expose kids to various disciplines.  That is a great thing.   Kids have to be shown what is out there so something ignites their instinctive passion.   BUT.    You are born to be a coder or engineer or scientist.   You can't force these disciplines on individuals.  It is part of their nature.  It is just a natural curiosity these folks have inside them that makes you passionate about these disciplines.    You can't just teach anyone coding then say you are going to be a coder or expect them to be a coder for life without their inner passion driving them.   Unfortunately more and more kids have NO passion for anything except thumbing their smart phones these days.   Technology is all around us today.  There's almost no escaping exposure to coding/computer technology.  That alone should get kinds interested in these fields.   But it doesn't.   The basic inner curiosity of kids today is just NOT there anymore.   Kids don't care about how it works or how is it done or where does it come from.  If living with all this technology doesn't spark their interest, throwing more money at this is not going to help.  The pioneering and exploitative spirit has been destroyed in kids because of all this feel good treatment of everyone's equal and everyone's a winner,  and diversity is good indoctrination they have received in the last few decades.   Then there is the I want it now so I deserve it mentality too.   There are winners and there are losers.  It's a fact of life.   Winners worked for what they achieved.   Losers got what they didn't work for.   Everyone can be a winner but it requires education, hard work and passion to succeed.    People succeed because they helped themselves primarily.   Outside influences and support are secondary and minor contributors to success.   Bottom line,  discipline, desire, hard work,  self sufficiency, empathy for others, and patience for working towards goals needs to be taught in schools again.    Everything else will take care of itself automatically then.

We do not want to deny opportunity to people because an industry average salary will go down because its just bad economics and you just deny people opportunity which by most people standards consider immoral.

"Why not let everybody choose what they want to learn (which sometimes will be a market need, and sometimes their heart's desire) and give these 500 million dollars to WHATEVER they choose to study?"

No one is forcing anyone to go into the field of computer science. The reason why 500 million dollars is specifically going to computer science is because there is a high demand for individuals to go into computer science but they aren't, so they're trying to provide an environment in which kids can have the opportunity to learn computer science. i.e funding computer science programs in schools (This is the point of the entire video I do not know how you missed it)

"Also, I don't think race and gender should be qualifiers in grants or scholarships etc. It is absolutely ludicrous.
There are Black people from rich homes and White people from absolute garbage. The qualifier should be socioeconomic status and projected ability."

Well we're talking about the field of computer science which again is what the whole video is about. There is is an unrepresentative amount of women and minorities in computer science, so if you're not a race realist or think women belong in the home, it doesn't make sense why there is an unrepresentative amount of women and minorities in the field in a free market society abstracted from culture. Lets say in a perfect world there was equal opportunity to everyone, there will still probably be an unrepresentative backgrounds in certain fields i.e women and construction, but this is not true in the case of computer science, since primarily the problems that women and minorities deal with are stigma and lack of opportunity. So if you want to rectify this problem in computer science, which again is the point of this video, you put towards grants/scholarships to rectify it. Now this is the case in terms of grants and scholarships, in terms of education programs, where the money primarily was hinted to go towards, no one is gonna say this program is only for blacks or just for women in schools, you're delusional if you believe that. It does not have to be one or the other, you can address the unrepresentative minority and women problem in computer science and the lack of poor people going into computer science (stem in general). The issue requires a multifaceted approach to solve effectively.

It is assumed that minorities and females (and even more so female minorities) need assistance because they are underrepresented in computer fields. I've worked in IT (information technology, the broad category that encompasses computer related work even as a part of other fields) for nearly 4 decades, and "white males" are typically not in the majority, especially among coders (software developers) and DBA's (database admins & architects). Instead, people with Indian or Asian heritage, nearly evenly split between men and women, make up the majority of the IT workforce (often overwhelmingly). Our schools aren't producing enough graduates with the right skills, either because kids aren't interested or due to lack of funding. This leaves employers little choice but to hire from abroad (H1B) or offshore some or all of the work, which despite regulations and expenses still costs less and provides a more sufficient supply.
If you look at school demographics, you'll find that same mix represents the top scorers and the most likely to continue into college and advanced degrees. The typical definition of "minorities" refers to Blacks and Hispanics, who also tend to be at the bottom end of the spectrum both in school achievement and the IT workplace. As another commenter noted, Asian (and Indian) kids hate school just as much as anyone else, but their parents "get it" and try to turn their kids into high achievers whether they want to or not. The degree of parental involvement seems to have the most direct correlation with academic achievement, far more so than any racial, ethnic, or financial influence.
The "white privilege" no one defines properly is the result of valuing individual achievement and the responsibility and hard work that it takes to earn what you have, even if you might be better off in the short term giving the system responsibility for your needs and choices without regard for who ultimately pays the price.
So this program appears to be like many others attempting to equalize for those that don't have as much "white privilege" (above definition, not the common version which is racist in nature), and helps provide for the future so that we don't have to go abroad as much to keep up with IT demand. If this is the aim, then I'm all for it. But if the race or minority card is played to exclude anyone (regardless of race or minority), that's what many fear.

Dear Destin, while you seem to be presenting this initiative as apolitical and "inarguably good," as it involves the US government pitching in "at least $200 million in grant funds per year" from taxpayers, it is by definition political, and people may agree or disagree with it depending on their political beliefs.

Putting that aside for a moment, I want to point out that some of the language used in this video by yourself and others aroused a suspicion in me and seemed to betray an underlying political motive, which you deny.

Example #1:
"I wanted to thank Ivanka for being such a champion, particularly of diversity, for girls, for African-Americans, for Hispanic-Americans [...]"
- Hadi Partovi, Founder and CEO of Code.org, at 4:50

Example #2:
"[...] My goal is that in 5 years there's Computer Science in every single high school and that we have teachers who are also representative, that we have women teachers and that we have young people of colour teaching Computer Science."
- Mary Snapp, Microsoft, at 7:28

I visited the Code.org website you listed in the description of the video. This is the first sentence in their "About Us" page (code.org/about): "Code.org® is a non-profit dedicated to expanding access to computer science and increasing participation by women and underrepresented minorities."
This is followed by a breakdown of students in their courses by racial and gendered lines.
"For the second year in a row, underrepresented minorities make up 48% of students in our courses. Increasing diversity in computer science is foundational to our work, and we encourage you to read more about our efforts."

On that sentence, there is a link to another page solely dedicated to "diversity" and "equity," which speaks for itself (code.org/diversity).

The website also contains mention of their "Diversity Council" (code.org/about/diversity-council).

Destin, with all due respect, as someone who regularly enjoys SmarterEveryDay content, your endorsement of this initiative which upon even the most cursory of investigations reveals itself to be thoroughly couched in aspects of Neo-Marxist ideology and its appalling notions of social justice and identity politics appears to send a political message, even if unintended.

Put bluntly: you appear to be endorsing the allocation of funds, not only private, but also public, to disproportionately fund the education and advancement of certain groups such as females and racial/ethnic minorities over white males, while claiming that it is an "inarguably good" purpose detached from politics.

If you wish to avoid politicising this channel, then I advise you not comment on political actions and controversial topics such as the importance of "diversity" and identity politics.

First off, there isn't a 'left and right' political spectrum. It's not one dimensional. It's two dimensional, at the very least. You have conservative and liberal on the X axis and anarchy and totalitarianism on the Y axis. Almost no one fits with R or D (in the US) because that doesn't tell the whole story. And if we're being realistic, there's probably two separate charts for fiscal vs social issues as well.

Second, this isn't a charity move. This is utter desperation. As someone in the computer science industry, I can tell you we're ALWAYS hiring. We are flying in college juniors and seniors on their summer breaks from all over the world, paying for their housing and transportation, AND paying them a large salary to intern with us in the hopes that they'll join up when they graduate. And we're not the only ones who are doing this. Our top intern candidates right now (for just my team) are mulling over 3 and 4 different job offers. $500 million is a tiny investment in the future compared to what we're paying right now to try to fill our vacancies.

Ok, I think good-meaning philanthropy is always great, but I worry that much of this effort will be for naught. I understand that algorithms, robots, and other digital systems will be taking over swaths of service and transportation sector jobs and right NOW there is high demand for graduates from the computer sciences, but how long will this be true? You can't just dump eight million new web designers, programmers, and software engineers into the current job market; only a fraction of that would get picked up. And this is all made worse with higher and higher level programming languages greatly reducing production time and in the reasonably near future AI systems being able to write software for a client based on their verbal descriptions.

As positive as it is to assist people in high-demand job skill acquisition, it is a drop in the bucket in comparison to the need for full-time workweek hour reduction. Overproduction is arguably the most damaging issue facing the US economy.

Okay I don't usually do this on your videos Destin but let me do a bit of criticism on this.

I get that raising money for improving CS education in the US is great (well I mostly get it, being European I'm actually a little confused about how CS isn't already taught in your high schools) and yes I agree that we should focus on the positive initiatives regardless of whether those are heavily outbalanced by the negative ones.

How is that going to be put into practice exactly? Is this going to be taken care of by your ministry of education (if there's even such a thing)? What does it mean in practice? Hiring more teachers? Putting together a consistent curriculum? Training the teachers to this new curriculum and if so how long before a proper system is in place? Now if this is geared towards girls and minorities, how will this work in practice? Will it be up to each school to put in place some kind of awareness programme to encourage girls to take CS? How does this fit in with other ongoing programs like Google's Summer of Code for example?

I could go on and on but the bottom line is what are they (whoever "they" is) going to with this money in practical terms to achieve this goal?

I am a comp sci graduate. I cant stress enough how useful the skills you learn in comp sci are in real life. It teaches critical thinking, problem solving, system analysis & design, organization,  logic. The list goes on. In Japan many students have to take classes on critical thinking skills, literally solving riddles.  While its not directly practical for getting a job, at least it helps develop those skills. Programming on the other hand does the same, and is practical. You arent giving a guide book on how to solve a problem, or build a system in Comp Sci, you are given an idea for what you need to achieve, and tools to do so. You come up with the solution to the problem. You need to think, plan, execute. Definitely something we need to start teaching kids at a young age.

About coding, I really think the way to go is with Games.
There have been coding tools designed as games, however they get boring rather quickly.
Actual games keep the attention of the student far better because they actually present a challenge to be overcome, rather than being just another task, as is most learning nowadays.
My first contact with programming was with triggers and actions in the map editor of old RTS games.
The first actual game that featured programming in it's gameplay was Minecraft with Redstone logic curcuits. Then, mods added Lua programming and now there's a vanilla Programable block.
The latest one is Shenzen I/O, featuring low level Assembly coding.
Kerbal Space Program also has a mod that allows code to be run.
But the one that takes the cake is the aptly named Space Engineers. Featuring goddamn C# as a means of player-made code controling the virtual environment. Can't say it better. It's actual C# scripts you write and run inside the game. And the modding/creator community is ripe with examples of basic mouse controlled tank turrets to radar guided homing missiles. May not appease the politically correct crowd (seriously. Grow up. The world is not pink), because the game creators themselves stated the goal of the game is to create war machines. But that is the engineer's way of learning. To have your creativity challenged.

I remain unconvinced. Let's be honest, giant tech companies don't care about women in the workplace (or for anyone, for that matter). They only care about their bottom line. The more people (women) that go into CS, the more competition for positions, which means lower wages. It's no coincidence that the charity these conglomerates chose to give to is one that that'll benefit them (albeit indirectly). The PR is just a bonus.

Furthermore, why is it so important for women to go into CS anyway? Women and men traditionally tend to go in different fields. Women go more into fields that are more geared towards human interaction (Health, Education, Social Work) whereas men tend to go for more technical fields (Comp. Sci, Engineering). I don't see anyone up in arms about there not being enough men in nursing/human resources/childcare, or women in mining/waste disposal/construction. And even within their chosen professions, women tend to go for positions that they'll find more enjoyable, whereas men are more likely to go for positions that'll pay more. For example, in Medicine, women make up 56% of pediatricians, and only 16% of cardiologists. What makes computer science so special?

And how is this going to work, anyway? Through grants? I mean... why? Women tend not to go into CS because they don't want to go into CS. Women are already far more likely to go to college than men, and there already exist far more grants and scholarships for women than men. I could understand, say, CS grants for those with a background of poverty, but all of this just seems.... misguided to me.

What would I do with 500 million?
I'd start a business. To create jobs. To make money. So I could expand the business. To create more jobs. To make more money. To expand the business...
Specifically, I'd make a consulting/prototyping company. You have a neat idea for a new product, but lack the means to actually get a working prototype? Well, I'd be your guy.
Because as a poor mechanical engineering student with multiple projects ongoing and on my mind, I know all too well what it's like to have an idea on your mind, but having to struggle with improper/improvised tools to make it happen.
A company like that could have clients from universities to startups. Maybe even big companies interested in diversifying their products withouth having to expand their prototyping workshops.
The problem is that company would require a lot of versatility to undergo a myriad of different projects. One month we build a car, the next a plane, then a drum playing robot... That would require top tier skilled labor and a lot of potentially idle industrial capability. And that's very expensive.
COMPUTER SCIENCE IS NOT THE TICKET FOR A JOB OUT OF COLLEGE. Do not go into it for the "money"

I grew up in Kingston, Ontario, Canada. Now some may say the education is quite different from America but with experience and interaction the Americans that transferred in, the tech side is quite similar. I am currently 18 years old and on a path to a business degree, but ever since I was a kid had a strong interest in computer science. When I was 7 I was given my first computer, every couple years after that rebuilding it with help from my dad and learning the basics and fundamentals of code. In school I was rewarded with numerus technology and robotics awards. In school there was nothing but discouragement for me to go into computer science. Let’s start with the high school computer science classes, grade 9 I was graded with a 68%, why? If you were to progress ahead of the class, you would be docked marks. You would also be docked marks if people were to come over and ask you questions, and if they were to ask the teacher the questions he wouldn’t know how to answer. Grade 10, 11, and 12 were very similar, the teacher actually had no idea what he was doing. We had a beautiful brand new computer science lab with its own network separate from the schools, and brand new computers. The teacher made us go through code academy at our own speed the entire semester, most of us finished within a couple weeks, so we found out the admin logins and made a class wide Minecraft server to serve us the rest of the semester. The teacher didn’t teach one lesson. At the end of the semester we were given an exam, 40 out of the 100 marks were a crossword, not just any crossword, a crossword from the 90’s. One of the fill-ins for the crossword no joke was “What is a popular internet browser?” The answer was Netscape Navigator. Luckily it was only worth 40% of what we could assume was our total grade. Grades 11 and 12 didn’t have an exam, but all we did was code academy. When it came time to apply for schools I talked to the councilors at the school about computer science and all they did was encourage me to take more general pathways. Now I did have encouragement from the teachers of the clubs I was on, and there were teachers from other schools that helped a lot. The thing is sometimes people aren’t given the right positions in the school or there just aren’t enough teachers that know code to teach it. I don’t know what the solution is, funding is good but it only gets you so far. Just thought I would share my experience.

The reason for partisanship and bickering is there are actually very few things that everyone agrees on, including this. My own opinion for example is that government should be educating the children and this is a clear sign that government is failing. The fact that the tech industry wishes to invest in their future employees is great, but the very fact that it is necessary says there is something wrong with the current situation. In my opinion, that 500 million should be spent lobbying the government to improve education, or better yet, spend it starting a new party that will change the government. I taught myself programming back in the early 80's on a second hand apple plugged into a TV using the RF converter of a video recorder and a cassette recorder for storage. I learnt via hobby magazines and books borrowed from the library. Friends started telling me I could make good money from coding and I enrolled in university. I graduated with a Bsc in computer science as a mature age student in '91, it gave me the gift of scientific literacy and liberated myself and my young family from the "working poor". The only reason I could afford to go to university was the "socialist" education system we have here in Australia.

There were 160 students who started the same course with me, only 3 were female. Four years later only 12 of the original students graduated with me, all 3 women and all 4 mature age students were in that group of 12. The lack of women in the software industry is puzzling and there are many theories as to why women tend to avoid the field, none of which I find very convincing. If you go back to the 50's and 60's there were actually more female programmers than male, the first programmer back in the 1800's was Ada Lovelace, etc, etc... your sister can probably tell you more about the proud history of women in software than I can in a YT comment.

For anyone of any age or gender who can read and wants to learn coding the internet is a fantastic resource, I would have crawled over broken glass to have had such a resource back in the 80's. However to get your foot in the door as a professional software dev you will need more than just coding skills, you need a (lot of luck or) a BSc, preferably in CS, math or engineering. Combining other skills and experience with software engineering skills is where you will find the most interesting (and well paid) jobs. Most CS courses try to do that by including a second major such as logistics or electrical engineering but any STEM major (or industry experience) will do.

Yes its a good thing that these funds are being made available. Thats a no brainer.

However, some of these people are insufferable. "We need to promote diversity!". Why? Diversity is not a bad thing but neither is it in itself a good thing unless you judge people by their race or gender. It should never, ever be the goal. People are not all the same. They have different interests. And because of this, to enforce diversity with the goal of parity necessarily requires that people are either 1) forced into an area they don't enjoy or 2) are barred or hindered from joining a field they enjoy exclusively on the basis of superficial and irrelevant characteristics like race and gender, or both. This is not equality of opportunity. This is equality of outcome.

These funds should be available to all people interested, regardless of their skin tone or gender. There should not be preferential treatment towards any perceived "group".

The one thing that needs to be said: A lot of these companies who are donating are not really concerned with adding more computer scientists to be "fair and equitable for all". What they are concerned about is the ever rising salaries given as part of the competition to get the good computer scientists when the pool of talent does not meet the demand. Unfortunately, programs that encourage universal computer science education are going to drive down the price of CS expertise, and we will see the historically high salaries for CS majors fall dramatically when we reach the point where the number of new CS graduates matches or exceeds the demand. You can't simply pick a field that currently high salaries and expect that "Oh, if we educate everyone in this field, we can give everyone a chance to get a high salary!", as that's simply not how economics work. Labor supply and demand follow the same processes and other supply and demand curves: If you have a surplus of supply for a given demand, prices will drop. Great for the companies, no so great for current or prospective future CS majors.

Ingrouping and outgrouping is one of humanity's strongest social instincts. It's never going to go away. It's why we play sports, make war, create subcultures, and join clubs. There is always an us, and a them. That's not to say we shouldn't keep trying, true... but... this idea that 'if we could just.... and everything would be fixed' is ridiculously naive. I know he 'didn't say that'.. but he could have cut back on the gloss a bit.

The point about 'Who cares where the money comes from, it's here, use it!' Is certainly valid, if you ask me.. but the whys and wheres matter, in the end. We have terms like 'blood money' and 'tainted fruit' for exactly that reason.

Also, it's a bit telling that making a point of 'don't disagree, just cooperate.' without mentioning that some of the disagreements are valid issues that need resolving is abhorrent on a channel dedicated to sussing out the details of complicated systems. I have a strong feeling that the 'I don't want to talk politics' and his blatant sidestepping of mentioning any views (Other than making a point to say he disagreed with a lot of Obama's views) really translates to 'My fan base is science oriented, and are REAAALY not gonna be happy if I state my position'.

Oh, the pesky details. While the Presidential Memorandum (in other words, without the weight of an Executive Order) establishes the $200 million per year as a goal, there is no funding without the Congress. And it's entirely up to the Secretary of Education whether to ask for additional funds or to simply divert funds from other programs. Either strategy has to be approved by OMB. I hope these are additional funds that we have a way to pay for but, in any administration, we often play a zero-sum game where we rob Peter to pay Paul. Below is the pertinent paragraph from the memo. I sincerely hope it all comes to pass and I really like the way you addressed the issue. I'll share your video on Facebook to see how many of my Democratic friends pass out. Get the smelling salts ready. :-)

Funding level. The Secretary shall, to the extent consistent with law, establish a goal of devoting at least $200 million in grant funds per year to the promotion of high‑quality STEM education, including Computer Science in particular. Within 30 days of the Congress passing final appropriations for each fiscal year for which the priority established under subsection (a) of this section is in effect, the Secretary shall identify the grant programs to which the STEM priority will apply and estimate the total amount of such grant funds that will support high‑quality STEM education, including Computer Science. The Secretary shall communicate plans for achieving this goal to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB Director) each fiscal year.

The main problem, as I see it, isn't just what "they" believe versus what "we" believe. The main problem is the "echo chamber" where we hear only those who agree with us, and avoid hearing those who disagree. This can only increase polarization. To me, if we are to exhibit simple intellectual honesty, to strive to see things as they really are, then this requires we exit the echo chamber.

How to do this? First, no matter what I believe for myself, when discussing an issue in "mixed company" I always put myself right in the middle, and try to get opposing sides to convince me rather than fight with each other. Quite often we wind up agreeing on the vast majority of fundamentals, and realize the things causing the most disagreement often have the least affect on actual outcomes. Best of all, I generally learn more about the issue as a whole, which influences my own, private, position for the better.

Second, when asked where I stand in the political spectrum (this seems to always happen on first dates), I say: "I seek to maximize personal freedoms and I support responsible fiscal policies." Of course, I believe in far more than "just" this, but I find this statement opens doors with both liberals and conservatives.

Find a place in the middle. This will permit you to serve as the fulcrum in a discussion, a window between sides rather than a separating wall.

One of the biggest hurdles to integrating coding into schools that no one ever talks about, however, is the fact that that there is little to no cohesive teacher training out there in computer science. There is no teacher certification program in this area. Teachers who want to support learning how to code in schools like myself are left to taking the baptism by fire route in the thin slivers of time one might fine between planning and grading required for the classes we have to teach on our day job. If people truly want to support serious development of integrating learning how to code in schools, programs would be built to train teachers on the basic fundamentals so that we have a leg to stand on in our efforts to support our students. Otherwise, we are just the blind leading the blind - and yes, there is something to be said for the value of learning together, but there is also something to be said for the times when your students look to you for help and all you as a teacher can offer is moral support.

Imagine for a moment how much of a better place we could have been in right now had the Gates Foundation poured their hundreds of millions into supporting teacher training for computer science instead of the grand experiment of Common Core.
